description: Design a user flow for a core game interaction
input: Design the user flow for the inventory management screen. Players need to view items, equip gear, compare stats, salvage junk, and sort/filter their inventory.
expected_behavior: Produces a user flow diagram showing entry points, key actions, state transitions, and exit points. Includes wireframe description, input mapping for controller/keyboard, and accessibility considerations.
rubric: Flow covers all requested actions
Entry and exit points are clear
Includes input mapping for multiple devices
Accessibility considerations are addressed
Information hierarchy is logical

input: Design the combat HUD for Infinite Voyage. Players need to see: health, shield, stamina, ability cooldowns, minimap, enemy health bars, and damage numbers.
expected_behavior: Produces a HUD layout spec with element positioning, priority (what's always visible vs. contextual), sizing, and adaptive behavior. Considers screen real estate and readability at distance.
rubric: All requested elements are placed
Critical info (health) is most prominent
Contextual elements appear/hide appropriately
Layout works for multiple aspect ratios
Follows game UI best practices

description: Design an onboarding sequence for new players
input: Design the first-time player experience for Infinite Voyage. The player needs to learn: movement, combat basics, inventory, and their first quest. Keep it under 10 minutes.
expected_behavior: Produces an onboarding sequence with progressive disclosure, clear prompts, gated advancement (can't skip ahead), and integration with the narrative (not a dry tutorial).
rubric: Progressive disclosure (one concept at a time)
Under 10 minutes total
Integrated with narrative context
Each step has clear success criteria
Covers all four requested systems

description: Audit a design for accessibility compliance
input: Review our current dialogue system design for accessibility. We use color-coded response options (green = friendly, red = hostile, blue = neutral).
expected_behavior: Identifies color-only information as an accessibility failure. Recommends adding icons, text labels, or patterns in addition to color. References accessibility standards and provides specific fixes.
rubric: Identifies color-only information as a barrier
Recommends non-color alternatives
References accessibility standards
Provides actionable, specific fixes
Considers multiple disability types

description: Create a complete screen specification for a character select screen
input: Create a full Screen Specification for the character select screen in Infinite Voyage. The game has 4 playable classes (Navigator, Vanguard, Engineer, Specter), each with a 3D model preview, stat block, class ability summary, and lore blurb. Players must be able to compare classes side-by-side, rotate models, and confirm their selection before starting a new campaign.
expected_behavior: Produces a complete screen specification document following the Screen/Wireframe Specification Template. Includes information zones (header, model preview, stat comparison, footer), interactive elements with all states (default, hover, selected, disabled), layout responsiveness table, transitions, and an accessibility checklist specific to this screen.
rubric: All four classes are represented with preview, stats, abilities, and lore
Information zones are clearly defined with sizing and content
Interactive elements include all states (default, hover, selected, disabled, focus)
Layout responsiveness covers at least 3 screen sizes
Accessibility checklist is completed for this specific screen

description: Specify all interactions for a crafting screen including error states
input: Using the attached wireframe (see file: crafting-screen-wireframe.md), write a complete interaction specification for the Infinite Voyage crafting screen. Define every interactive element's behavior, all input mappings (keyboard, controller, mouse), state transitions, animation timings, and error states. Pay special attention to what happens when crafting fails, materials are insufficient, or inventory is full.
expected_behavior: Produces a detailed interaction spec covering every interactive element in the wireframe. Each element has defined states, input mappings for 3 input methods, feedback (visual + audio), and transition timing. Error states are fully specified with user-facing messages, recovery paths, and visual treatment. Includes edge cases like mid-craft disconnection and station tier restrictions.
rubric: Every interactive element from the wireframe has a complete behavior spec
Input mappings cover keyboard, controller, and mouse for each action
At least 4 error states are fully defined with messages and recovery paths
Animation and transition timings are specified in seconds/milliseconds
Audio feedback is defined for key interactions (craft success, failure, selection)

description: Adapt a HUD layout from 1080p to 4K, ultrawide, and mobile
input: Using the attached HUD element list (see file: hud-element-list.md), define the complete responsive scaling rules to adapt the Infinite Voyage combat HUD from its 1080p baseline to: (1) 4K at 3840x2160, (2) ultrawide at 3440x1440, and (3) mobile landscape at 2560x1080 with touch controls. For each resolution, specify how every element repositions, resizes, or restructures. Address DPI scaling, minimum touch target sizes, and readability at each resolution.
expected_behavior: Produces a comprehensive scaling specification for all 16 HUD elements across 3 target resolutions. Includes a scaling strategy (pixel-based vs percentage-based vs hybrid), per-element rules for position and size at each resolution, DPI considerations for 4K, ultrawide safe-zone handling for edge elements, and mobile-specific adaptations (touch targets at least 44x44pt, thumb-zone placement). Elements that hide, merge, or restructure at certain resolutions are explicitly called out.
rubric: All 16 HUD elements have defined behavior at each of the 3 target resolutions
Scaling strategy is clearly stated and consistently applied
4K spec addresses DPI scaling so elements are not too small
Ultrawide spec handles horizontal safe zones and element repositioning
Mobile spec defines touch targets (minimum 44x44pt) and thumb-zone placement

description: Propose diegetic alternatives for non-diegetic UI elements
input: Infinite Voyage currently uses these non-diegetic (traditional overlay) HUD elements: (1) a rectangular health bar in the bottom-left corner, (2) a floating minimap in the top-right corner, and (3) pop-up text notifications for quest updates that appear center-screen. Propose diegetic alternatives for each — UI that exists within the game world rather than overlaid on the screen. The game is set in a sci-fi universe where players wear exosuits with helmet visors. Consider immersion, readability, and accessibility trade-offs for each proposal.
expected_behavior: Produces 3 diegetic UI proposals, one per element. Each proposal describes the in-world representation (e.g., health bar as a light strip on the player's arm), how it communicates the same information as the non-diegetic version, where it appears in the game world, and how the camera/player interacts with it. Each proposal includes an accessibility fallback (option to revert to non-diegetic for players who need clearer readability). Trade-offs between immersion and usability are explicitly discussed.
rubric: All 3 elements receive a distinct diegetic alternative grounded in the sci-fi setting
Each proposal explains how the same information is communicated in-world
Readability trade-offs are discussed (e.g., diegetic health harder to read at a glance)
Accessibility fallback to non-diegetic mode is provided for each element
At least one proposal includes a sketch or ASCII wireframe of the in-world element

description: Define all error and edge case states for the item equipment screen
input: Using the attached error scenarios (see file: equipment-error-scenarios.md), define the complete UI response for each of the 6 error/edge-case scenarios on the Infinite Voyage equipment screen. For each scenario, specify: the exact error message text, visual treatment (colors, icons, animations), which UI elements change state, what the player's recovery options are, and how the UI prevents the error from recurring. Include wireframe sketches of at least 2 of the error states.
expected_behavior: Produces a complete error state specification covering all 6 scenarios. Each scenario includes: a user-facing error message (concise, actionable), visual treatment (color, icon, animation), affected UI element states, 1-2 recovery paths the player can take, and a prevention mechanism (e.g., graying out invalid items before selection). At least 2 scenarios include ASCII wireframe sketches showing the error state layout. The tone of error messages is helpful and non-punishing.
rubric: All 6 error scenarios have complete UI specifications
Error messages are concise, actionable, and use a helpful tone
Visual treatment uses color, icons, and animation — not color alone
Each scenario defines at least one clear recovery path for the player
At least 2 error states include wireframe sketches showing the UI layout
